text: in this video we'll be discussing noun
Clauses with wh
words this is the second type of noun
clause uh noun Clauses with whw are
again dependent
clauses but with these types of noun
Clauses we don't start the noun clause
with that instead we started with a wh
word such as when how which and so
on so noun clauses with wh words look
like questions because they use the wh
words but when we write these noun
Clauses we use statement order instead
of question order in other words we
start with a subject and then a verb and
then sometimes
object we don't use question word
order and we also do not use a question
mark at the end of the
statement so let's look look at a couple
of examples so we'll start with a wh
question very simple one when is the
test we want to change this into a noun
clause with the wh word so we need to
start with the independent
clause here's an example the students
know so our independent clause is the
students subject no verb and here's the
question but we've changed it into a whw
noun clause so we started with the same
whw
when but we switched the verb and
subject around so that it's in statement
form or statement word
order and we end up with when the test
is so we have the students know when the
test is here's another
example what will she do tomorrow this
is the w question now we want to change
it into a wh noun
clause so we can say she
knows we have the subject and
verb we put in the wh word same wh word
what she will do tomorrow so again
notice that the helping verb and the
subject they switch back around
to statement word
order here's one more example when did
he write the
essay when we turn it into a noun
clause he remembers when he wrote the
essay so here remember that when we
write a question we have to add do do
has a past tense but when we change it
into a statement the past tense goes
onto the main
verb and it turns into wrote
here's some more
examples here are three wh
questions and you guys can try to change
these into wh noun Clauses and I'll give
you some examples
answers
so as you can see in all of these
answers we start with the independent
clause we build the independent
clause make sure you have a subject and
verb then we start the wh noun clause
with the wh words then we change the
question word order into statement word
order so that we have for example
subject verb an
object now we're going to talk about
some common errors two common errors the
first common error is using that and a
whw in the same sentence so for example
the student wants to know that how
people learn languages so we see right
here that is for a statement type noun
clause and how is for a wh type noun
clause we can't use
both so to fix this error we have uh the
student wants to know that how people
learn languages we just need to get rid
of one of the words that starts to noun
clause so I'm going to take out
that and we have the student wants to
know how people learn languages so we
have a wh question turned into a noun
clause the second common error is using
using question form in a noun
clause
so we can see for example the teacher
explained why did they need to study so
you see right here this wh noun clause
it's still in question word
order so again it's incorrect we need to
change
this uh we start with the teacher
explained why did they need to
study and we switch the verb and subject
into noun clause or statement word order
so we end up with the teacher explained
why they needed remember it's in past
tense did to
study
